description: The product of the same kind of environment and pressure that produced baile funk in Rio and kwaito in South Africa, the Angolan take on dance music called kuduro has a wonderful set of ambassadors in Buraka Som Sistema. M.I.A. guests on their debut album.

title: Johnny Cash Remixed
label: Compadre
description: Totally inessential.

title: Blood Bank EP
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Blood Bank EP

title: Exotic Creatures of the Deep
label: Lil' Beethoven
description: L.A. underground rock institution follows a recent upswing that began with 2002's Lil' Beethoven with a joke-filled album that explores the collision of dignity and indignity.

title: Tail Swallower & Dove
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: As do mathy post-hardcore bands, Seattle-based These Arms Are Snakes deploy winding time signatures, grinding guitars, and strained, often obtuse lyrics. Here on their third full-length, they also manage a few left turns.

title: 1-2-3/Apple Tree EP / Next Year in Zion
label: Everloving
description: 1-2-3/Apple Tree EP / Next Year in Zion

title: Radio Retaliation
label: Eighteenth Street Lounge
description: Will people host tasteful, upmarket dinner parties during the economic recession? Thievery Corporation hope so.

title: The Crying Light
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On The Crying Light, Antony Hegarty remains fascinated with the transitions and overlaps between birth and life, life and death, this world and the next, but he expresses them in more universal, more direct, but no less rapturous terms than he did on his New York-tinted breakthrough I Am a Bird Now.

title: Cranes
label: Dadaphonic
description: On their ninth studio disc, these first-wave shoegazers continue their move in the direction of glimmering electronic melodies and gently contemplative song structures that highlight Alison Shaw's unique voice.

title: Haymaker!
label: Yep Roc
description: The exclamation point in the title of the Gourds' latest album doesn't lie: The Austin-based band plays an emphatic, exclamatory amalgam of Americana styles, ambling through pre-rock country, bluegrass, rockabilly, and Texas swing.

title: We Ate the Machine
label: MySpace
description: Japan's Polysics traffic in Devo-inspired synth-punk always on the edge of chaos, and their latest places a greater emphasis on guitars and rock heaviness.

title: We Mean Business
label: EP
description: Fresh off the nostalgia circuit, EPMD return with a surprisingly enjoyable reminder of the potency of a group often overshadowed by their more name-dropped contemporaries. Raekwon, Method Man, 9th Wonder, and Redman guest.

title: Live from Las Vegas at the Palms
label: iTunes
description: For anyone turned off by the band's recent experiments, My Morning Jacket offer a short but sweet reminder of why so many people love them in the first place.

title: Fun DMC
label: Gold Dust Media
description: On their latest record, Fun DMC, P.U.T.S. happily exalt the mundane, turning the everyday material of urban existence into tunes suggesting that life ought to be lived as an eternal weekend.

title: A Town Called Addis
label: Realworld
description: Nick Page, aka Dub Colossus, traveled to Ethiopia and back to bridge reggae music with its spiritual homeland.

title: Titan: It's All Pop!
label: Numero Group
description: The Numero Group unearths forgotten turn-of-the-1980s power pop and new wave from the tiny Kansas City label Titan.

title: Nodzzz
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: Despite a distinctly lo-fi aesthetic, Nodzzz sound less like noise-pop contemporaries such as Vivian Girls or Crystal Stilts and more like 70s pub-rock or Modern Lovers.

title: Glasvegas
label: Columbia
description: Heavily touted in the UK press after an excellent single for their combination of girl-group pop structures, wall of sound production, and Jesus and Mary Chain-style guitar buzz, Scotland's Glasvegas hook up with Muse and Mars Volta producer Rich Costey for their full-length debut.

title: Olly Oxen Free
label: Dovecote
description: Michigan band's second full-length, produced by TV on the Radio associate Chris Coady, swings from relatively straightforward indie rock to looser and more abstract moments that are hard to classify.

title: Jewels
label: Potomak
description: Einstürzende Neubauten's latest culls from the third phase of a Supporter Project-- where fans funded the production of their previous record, Alles Wieder Offen, in return for a song a month-- and is steeped in the band's past work, with parts assembled from moments or passages or moods in the Neubauten discography.

title: Emeritus
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: Unrelentingly bleak and angry but not without its pop flourishes, the latest from the Houston MC solidifies his position as an elder statesman of hip-hop.

title: Fantasy Black Channel
label: Parlophone
description: This Erol Alkan-produced UK band's debut LP strives to compress the electro-pop/indie-dance 80s into a dozen MP3s, providing an engaging twist on one of the decade's most familiar sounds.

title: Where Were U in 92?
label: Werk Discs
description: Zomby follows his buzzed-about dubstep singles with... a full-length 'ardkore throwback album. In the process he reveals himself as a provocative genre-tweaker able to nimbly move-- historically and stylistically-- throughout rave, garage, and jungle.

title: Army Navy
label: Fever Zone
description: Singer and songwriter Justin Kennedy joins former Attractions member Pete Thomas and several others to create a buoyant valentine to the power pop of the late 1970s and early 80s.

title: Oh! Mighty Engine
label: Brushfire
description: The second solo album from the former Slowdive and Mojave 3 leader finds him sounding less like he's hiding from the English rain and more like he's soaking in the California sun.

title: Steps to Heaven / Charlie Louvin Sings Murder Ballads and Disaster Songs
label: Tompkins Square
description: Steps to Heaven / Charlie Louvin Sings Murder Ballads and Disaster Songs

title: Black Secret Technology
label: Juice Box
description: Long considered a contender for the title of "best jungle album ever," A Guy Called Gerald's 1995 classic Black Secret Technology returns in newly mastered form.

title: Picture Book
label: Sanctuary
description: In part compiled by Ray Davies, this mostly chronological jumble of singles, album tracks, alternate mixes, mono versions, live cuts, rarities, hits, misses, and even a couple demos and one rehearsal attempts the Herculean task of compiling the Kinks' four-decade career into one 6xCD box.

title: My Magic City
label: End Up
description: Solo debut from the vocalist of now-defunct Rainer Maria, mostly recorded live and in intimate settings, offers instrumental chops and narrative intrigue.

title: Songs from the Beehive
label: Smallville
description: Two veteran German producers come together for an outstanding album that, despite its lengthy tracks, remains oddly accessible. Here they draw on all the styles they've touched on in the past, from dubby minimal techno to house to ambient.

title: Living Is Hard: West African Music in Britain, 1927-1929
label: Honest Jon's
description: The latest archival release on Damon Albarn's Honest Jon's imprint collects early 78 sides containing spare folk songs, primarily from Ghana and Nigeria, many of which are delivered a cappella.

title: Fabric 43
label: Fabric
description: Morgan Geist and Darshan Jesrani's Metro Area are best known for a lusciously restrained take on disco, but for their entry in Fabric's peerless DJ series they've turned in something closer to a party mix.

title: Live at Park Avenue EP
label: ThinkIndie
description: The nine-song, half-hour Live At Park Avenue EP (available via ThinkIndie or in certain independent record stores) aims to keep live recordings relevant at a time when they, like recorded music itself, are both ubiquitous and easily acqiured by illegal means.

title: Reverse Migration
label: Our Secret
description: Despite appearances from Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor and Air's Jean-Benoît Dunckel, this Au Revoir Simone remix album is as hit-and-miss as the average Hype Machine chart.

title: XOXO, Panda and the New Kid Revival
label: Mush
description: Veteran lap-pop artist Marc Bianchi takes a detour here, crafting an unplugged record that finds him moving to more traditional instrumentation and songwriting.

title: The Lilac Time
label: Labrador
description: Indie pop songwriter offers his third album of nostalgic tunes delivered with caustic wit, self-deprecating humor, and absurdly catchy melodies.

title: Lemonade
label: True Panther
description: With a muscular, aggressive approach to dance music, Lemonade operate from a similar base as other percussive post-punk new-schoolers, from party-starting outfits like !!! and Professor Murder to more abrasive acts like Aa and Liars.

title: No Pussyfooting / Evening Star
label: Island
description: No Pussyfooting / Evening Star

title: Moenie and Kitchi
label: Fat Cat
description: Producer Adam Pierce of Bubblecore/Mice Parade fame adds his distinctive arrangements to the skeletal songs of Meredith Godreau.

title: Miniatures
label: Gaarden
description: Matthew Robert Cooper maintains the deep-seated ache that characterizes his music as Eluvium, offering an album of orchestral and electronic sketches drawn from a yet-to-be-completed symphony.

title: Akh Issudar
label: World Village
description: Founded by former members of desert rock standard bearers Tinariwen, this Tuareg guitar outfit's sound is even more stripped down and elemental while their songs visit now-familiar themes of exile and loneliness.

title: Easy Come Easy Go
label: Naïve
description: This covers album finds the 60s legend working with Antony, Jarvis Cocker, and Cat Power and tackling songs by Morrissey, Brian Eno, the Decemberists, Neko Case, and Duke Ellington, among others.

title: The 4-Track Era Bundle
label: djshadow.com
description: The man behind statements like "In/Flux" and Endtroducing..... proves that he was steeped in classic hip-hop fundamentals.

title: Punkgasm
label: Relapse
description: Virtuosic playing, inventive drumming evocative of jazz, and absurdist songs titles like "The Irrespective Dick Area" are all here, but Don Cab still feels a long way from their turn-of-the-millenium peak.

title: Fire on Corridor X
label: Killer Pimp
description: Atlanta's All the Saints revive the turn-of-the-90s days when grunge and shoegaze were still vibrant underground sounds.

title: Wreckless Eric & Amy Rigby
label: Stiff
description: Wreckless Eric, known for a few early new wave hits on the Stiff label, teams with his wife, singer-songwriter Amy Rigby, for an album of quirky, homemade pop.

title: Slumdog Millionaire OST
label: N.E.E.T.
description: The smash Mumbai-set Danny Boyle film is propelled as much by its soundtrack as it is by its fantasy plot, as demonstrated by A.R. Rahman's propulsive M.I.A.-assisted score.

title: Diplo & Benzi Present: Fear & Loathing in Hunts Vegas
label: Paper Route Empire
description: The Paper Route Gangstaz-- Huntsville, Ala.'s answer to No Limit, Cash Money, or the Dungeon Family-- hook up with hipster-DJ kingpins Diplo and Benzi for a mixtape that turns out to best highlight the crew rather than the producers.

title: Curtain Speech EP
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: The debut EP from this Brooklynite features contributions from Asthmatic Kitty labelmates Sufjan Stevens, Shara Worden, and Rafter.

title: The Living and the Dead
label: Anti-
description: With guitar contributions from M. Ward and Marc Ribot, the fourth album from this Texas-born, New York-based singer-songwriter is both her most cohesive and most eclectic.

title: Live in London and Paris
label: Stax
description: Culled from two 1967 performances drawing on almost identical setlists, Live in London and Paris captures Redding at the full height of his powers as a showman, inviting even the casual fan to lean close to listen for each staging's distinctive qualities.

title: The Effects of 333
label: Abstract Dragon
description: This is, no shit, a background noise record released on BRMC's own label. In the band's own words: "No apologies, no lyrics, no regrets, just abstract." Well, an apology would have been nice.

title: GhostDeini the Great
label: Def Jam
description: Stuck between a best-of and a remix collection (featuring appearances by Kanye West, Lil Wayne, Clipse, Raekwon, and Ice Cube), GhostDeini the Great undercuts the strengths that would've been present in a disc devoted to one format or the other.

title: Theater of the Mind
label: Disturbing Tha Peace
description: Following his 2007 mixtape with DJ Drama, The Preview, Ludacris returns with a star-studded full-length that includes guest spots from the Game, Nas, Jay-Z, and T.I. and production from Swizz Beats, DJ Premier, and 9th Wonder.

title: Luna
label: Pet Rock
description: Three ex-members of the much-missed Beta Band continue to veer between experimentalism and pop songcraft as the Aliens.

title: Friendly Fires
label: XL
description: This English indie-dance trio's debut shows an amplified, ambitious, and inventive attention to detail that helps steer them away from sounding like just another polished party band.

title: Zang Tumb Tuum: The ZTT Box Set
label: ZTT
description: This 25-year anniversary celebration of Trevor Horn and Paul Morley's famous imprint makes the case that ZTT was Britain's most interesting label for five years-- and then it plodded along for another 20.

title: Merriweather Post Pavilion
label: Domino
description: Merriweather Post Pavilion

title: Changing of the Seasons
label: Cheap Lullaby
description: Dependable Scandinavian singer-songwriter Ane Brun returns with another record of spare instrumentation, slightly broken sentiment, and an unwavering devotion to prettiness.

title: Give Me Love: Songs of the Brokenhearted - Baghdad 1925-1929
label: Honest Jon's
description: Collecting recordings of small ensembles found in and around Baghdad in the late 1920s, this compilation sheds light on a misunderstood region whose recent history obscures its cultural legacy.

title: Original Darkness
label: Kranky
description: Through her solo work and as a member of Charalambides, Christina Carter has long been an expert avant-folk minimalist, mining depth from small, repetitive songs.

title: To Be Free: The Nina Simone Story
label: Legacy
description: This invaluable box set traces the legendary career of Nina Simone from her first recording session to one of her last, as she marches through Duke Ellington, Kurt Weill, torch songs, folk songs, and the pop and rock hits of her day.

title: Christmas on Mars
label: Warner Bros.
description: After seven years, the Flaming Lips' Christmas film finally comes to DVD; not surprisingly, both the movie and its soundtrack reflect the Lips circa 2001 more than the group's post-millennial output, which has emphasized the band's cute and quirky qualities while submerging the strange.

title: The Uglysuit
label: Quarterstick
description: Young Oklahoma City band debuts with an album that references several strains of iconic indie rock, from the jangly pop of the Shins to the jammier moments of Wilco.

title: I'll Stay 'Til After Christmas
label: AWR
description: This Amnesty International benefit album collects yuletide songs from indie heavyweights such as Blitzen Trapper, My Brightest Diamond, Sally Shapiro, Belong, Au Revoir Simone, and Jimmy Tamborello's Figurine project.

title: Welcome to the Welcome Wagon
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Recorded, engineered, mixed, and designed by Sufjan Stevens (he also wrote the liner notes, released it on his label, Asthmatic Kitty, and contributes vocals and music), Welcome to the Welcome Wagon sounds an awful lot like...a Sufjan Stevens album.

title: The Soul of Rock And Roll
label: Monument
description: This 4xCD box set is the most expansive and exhaustive summary of the rock'n'roll legend's long career, which had its share of ups and downs and ended on an impossibly high note with his 1989 album Mystery Girl and his work with the Traveling Wilburys.

title: Road to Till the Casket Drops
label: self-released
description: A quickie free mixtape intended to celebrate the launch of Clipse's new clothing line Play Cloths, Road to Till the Casket Drops is well worth your half-hour and zero dollars.

title: TV Loves You Back
label: Anticon
description: An indie-rap supergroup of sorts, this Anticon act presents a furious, righteous, and not entirely subtle dissatisfaction with capitalism.

title: 1970's Algerian Proto-Raï Underground
label: Sublime Frequencies
description: Every bit the people's music as much as punk or hip-hop, raï has been flourishing for decades, even after post-colonial Marxist governments pushed it underground. Sublime Frequencies' vinyl-only compilation celebrates some of the best raï from Algeria's darker cultural years.

title: BM
label: Monika
description: The Berlin-based producer here embraces a heady avant-pop approach, using electronics sparingly as she moves her voice and piano work to the center of her music. Robert Wyatt guests.

title: Universal Mind Control
label: Geffen
description: On Be and Finding Forever, Common struck a winning, humanizing balance between moralism and hedonism, proving that the two needn't be mutually exclusive. On Universal Mind Control, he-- and the Neptunes-- split his personalities into what seem like two wildly different EPs.

title: Brighten the Corners: Nicene Creedence Ed.
label: Matador
description: Matador's deluxe Pavement reissue campaign continues with Brighten the Corners, the underrated record that signaled the group's turn toward the serious and mature. Also included are 32 outtakes and radio-session cuts that more accurately reflect the loose, ramshackle feel of the group's early-to-mid 1990s work.

title: Japanese Motors
label: Vice
description: Fronted by a former pro surfer and fleshed out by a bunch of dudes who look like the male cast of "The Hills", Japanese Motors sound like a West Coast version of the Strokes or Black Lips.

title: Everything/Everything
label: Tomlab
description: The eccentric Englishman, who has worked with Saint Etienne and remixed Grizzly Bear and Franz Ferdinand, embraces organic instrumentation and pop song structure on this kitchen-sink examination of the Information Age.

title: Brown Submarine
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: Robert Pollard's new band with Guided by Voices pal Chris Slusarenko and drummer John Moen of the Decemberists seems to have reinvigorated the prolific songwriter. Shedding the bloat and eccentricities of his recent projects, Brown Submarine is as direct and tuneful as anything since GBV's heyday.

title: The Finally LP
label: Caldo Verde
description: The Sun Kil Moon/Red House Painters singer-songwriter ends the year with yet another quality release-- this time, a record of lovely instrumentals and covers of tracks from tribute and benefit albums.

title: A Cross the Universe
label: Atlantic
description: Recorded from mics set around the stage rather than the soundboard, this live Justice record is as much about the audience as it is the artist; a DVD documentary adds entertaining on-the-road footage.

title: Ropechain
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Indiana native puts pop culture references and musical genres into a blender to create a weird and druggy concoction that sometimes evokes early Ween.

title: Hush Arbors
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: Nearly a decade into their career, and after quite a few low-profile releases, Virginia's Hush Arbors bring their delicate but experimental brand of folk to Thurston Moore's Ecstatic Peace imprint.

title: Holiday
label: Milan
description: The second album from Brandon Bethancourt's project moves away from the Zach Condon-assisted Balkan folk of his debut to embrace sleek, mechanized indie pop.

title: Dark End of the Street EP
label: Matador
description: Cat Power closes the year as she started it: with a record of covers. This time she tackles songs made famous by Aretha Franklin, CCR, and the Pogues, among others.

title: Alone II: The Home Recordings of Rivers Cuomo
label: Geffen
description: This sequel to last year's vault-digging Alone is less revelatory than the first volume, but it nearly matches its predecessor in quality.

title: Peoria
label: Star Apple Kingdom
description: Peoria is the second album from the Austin band led by Robert Harrison, formerly of Cotton Mather. Though still heavy on the Beatles worship, Peoria is a vast improvement on the group's bloated 2xCD debut.

title: Kitsuné Maison 6: The Melodic One
label: Kitsuné
description: The sixth Kitsuné Maison compilation in three years finds the French dance label leaning slightly in the direction of more song-oriented material. Artists include Fischerspooner, A-Trak, Grovesnor, and Heartsrevolution, among others.

title: Burnt Out Landscapes
label: Magic Marker
description: Two years after a debut full of fashionable reference points and catchy, well-crafted songs, Manhattan Love Suicides release a 27-song compilation of the C86-inspired rockers' best material, which proves they still have room to explore some different directions.

title: Sugar Mountain: Live at Canterbury House 1968
label: Reprise
description: Taken from his first two post-Buffalo Springfield solo acoustic concerts, Neil Young's new archival material finds the singer locating his voice-- which, even at 23, sounded weathered and experienced.

title: Day & Age
label: Island
description: After the unlearned pop bent of Hot Fuss and the clichéd strained seriousness of Sam's Town, the Killers return with a third album that aims to split the difference between its predecessors.

title: Adventure
label: Carpark
description: The debut full-length from Benny Boeldt of the Baltimore-based Wham City collective recalls the wonky buzzsaws of late-80s video game chiptunes with a focus on the exuberant melodies and dance rhythms of early synthpop.

title: Ladyhawke
label: Modular
description: New Zealand native Pip Brown drops her debut full-length as Ladyhawke, an electro-pop project that blends glitzy choruses and pinpoint synthesizers as heard on the minor hit "Paris Is Burning".

title: Acoustics EP
label: Tigre Blanco
description: As you may have guessed from the title, this is Minus the Bear unplugged, with one new song and six photocopies of old songs played essentially the same way as the originals with slightly different instruments.

title: Beauty Dies EP / Wishing You a Rave Christmas EP
label: Vice
description: The last two of the Raveonettes' four digital-only 2008 EPs-- one an 80s throwback, the other a holiday collection-- are also their best.

title: Esau Mwamwaya and Radioclit are the Very Best
label: Green Owl
description: Malawian-born, London-based singer Esau Mwamwaya teams with the European production team Radioclit for a hugely eclectic mixtape. While strong collaborations with M.I.A., Santogold, and Vampire Weekend include some surprising left turns, tracks that lean away from the familiar work even better.

title: Far Flung Hum
label: Wodger
description: After adding glitchy electronics in the vein of Markus Popp or Christian Fennesz on last year's Communal Rust, former Kranky group Christmas Decorations take another step forward on Far Flung Hum, the group's first release on their own label.

title: Challenger
label: Hospital Productions
description: Latest from C. Spencer Yeh's drone project marks a shift in tone as he moves away from the harsh industrial sound of recent releases.

title: Welcome to the Night Sky
label: Labwork
description: The third album from these 2008 Juno Award winners from Halifax, Nova Scotia, finds them further refining their brand of jangly, affecting indie rock while subtly laying groundwork for future experimentation.

title: Black Sea
label: Touch
description: Black Sea, which again finds experimental electronic music star Christian Fennesz working primarily with guitar and computer, is his first solo album since 2004's Venice, and it's reminiscent of classical pieces-- sweeping and symphonic and patiently unfolding*.*

title: The Reminder: Deluxe Edition
label: Cherrytree
description: Coupled with a bonus disc filled with videos, remixes, demos, and rarities, this reissue of Feist's breakthrough record reminds us that before the Apple ads and YouTube hits, she recorded a near-perfect batch of broken-hearted tunes.

title: Beating Back the Claws of the Cold
label: Hardly Art
description: Ryan Barrett fronts this literate Pacific Northwest indie-pop outfit on the Sub Pop offshoot Hardly Art.

title: Walking on a Dream
label: EMI
description: The first full-length collaboration from Australians Luke Steele of the Sleepy Jackson and Nick Littlemore of Pnau works on a grand scale as it moves between streamlined psychedelia and flamboyant dance-pop.

title: I Love Dubstep
label: Rinse FM
description: This well-curated two-man mix courtesy of the pioneering pirate station Rinse FM is a good bet for new listeners interested in the bigger dubstep picture-- even if it's already sounding a little more like time-capsule material than the way forward.

title: My Mistakes Were Made for You EP
label: Domino
description: After an impressive album of cinematic, late-1960s pop, Arctic Monkey Alex Turner's Last Shadow Puppets offers this U.S.-only release, which compiles UK B-sides plus four stripped-down live tracks.

title: 808s and Heartbreak
label: Roc-A-Fella
description: 808s and Heartbreak

title: Rio
label: Nacional
description: The latest album from Colombia's Aterciopelados continues their unique fusion of styles, integrating elements of Mongolian throat-singing, cumbia, and jerk funk into their rock sound.

title: Remind Me in 3 Days
label: Interscope
description: Hotly tipped New Orleans-to-L.A. rap duo debuts with an album heavy on hands-up choruses, rock overtones, and agile raps that are playful enough to counter lapses into misogyny.

title: Dolores
label: Ipecac
description: German band whose music is a unique blend of metal, jazz, and ambient returns with an album of eerie anti-social cocktail music on Mike Patton's Ipecac label.

title: Always the Bridesmaid EP
label: Capitol
description: This year, Colin Meloy and co. released a series of three vinyl singles, joined under the shared title Always the Bridesmaid, that-- after the sometimes overblown The Crane Wife-- offer a welcome return to more modest song forms.

title: Chinese Democracy
label: Black Frog
description: After a 17-year wait, Chinese Democracy needs to be a spectacle-- something that either validates its tortuous birthing process or a Hindenberg so horribly panned it somehow validates its mastermind as a misunderstood genius.

title: The Way of All Flesh
label: Listenable
description: Production has always been as important to Gojira's attack as note choice, and the metal band's new album is an audiophile's wet dream.

title: The Singing Saw at Christmastime
label: Merge
description: Julian Koster is best known as the banjo and saw player in Neutral Milk Hotel, and on his solo debut he wields his saw for a series of classic Christmas songs.

title: Limbo, Panto
label: Domino
description: The debut album from the UK's unique Wild Beasts is essentially a morality play as cabaret show as rollicking indie rock record.

title: Love Train: The Sound of Philadelphia
label: Sony
description: This 71-track compilation of the best of Philly soul is packed with songs that range from good to absolutely crucial, and it provides an excellent look at a once-maligned, now-often-beloved sound.

title: Something About Airplanes
label: Barsuk
description: This Barsuk reissue features some ho-hum selections from Death Cab's first live show and a Smiths cover, but its real draw is the chance to re-evaluate a band that for many is still considered a dealbreaker.

title: Eccentric Soul: The Young Disciples
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group unearth another rewarding Eccentric Soul volume, both for its story and amazing music, which this time comes courtesy of East St. Louis' the Young Disciples.

title: Drippers EP
label: 70s Gymnastics
description: This limited-edition, scratch'n'sniff EP (no, seriously) is the follow-up to 2007 breakout Dandelion Gum.

title: The '59 Sound
label: SideOneDummy
description: The Gaslight Anthem are Jersey punks enamored with Springsteen, Social Distortion, and the Clash, and their wholehearted embrace of familiar rock'n'roll tropes winds up being a huge part of their charm.

title: Wu: The Story of the Wu-Tang Clan
label: Legacy
description: If you need a one-hour primer to Wu-Tang circa 1993-2000, you could do a lot worse than this record, created to accompany a BET documentary on the early days of the legendary hip-hop collective.

title: Prospekt’s March EP
label: Capitol
description: This eight-track stopgap EP-- which doubles as a bonus disc on the obligatory Viva fourth-quarter deluxe edition-- allows for an assessment of Coldplay's 2008 "We Are Edgy" campaign. Jay-Z guests.

title: Canopy Glow
label: Anticon
description: Blog-rock 06 vets still sound like Sufjan Stevens despite releasing their latest on hip-hop label Anticon.

title: You'll Never Play This Town Again
label: Load
description: This 42-track compilation features a trio of live records, a handful of singles, and an untitled studio record from just about the most abrasive band America has ever seen.

title: Tronic
label: Fat Beats
description: Detroit producer and Slum Village associate continues to work at a very high level, with hard-hitting beats and textures ready for both clubs and headphones. Guests include Pharoahe Monch, DJ Premier, and Royce da 5'9".

title: Electric Arguments
label: One Little Indian
description: Paul McCartney resurrects his long-dormant alter ego, teams with producer Youth, and makes an album that can honestly be called "Beatleseque."

title: Murmur [Deluxe Edition]
label: IRS
description: The legendary band reissues and remasters its debut, and still arguably best, album, adding a bonus disc that marks the first time a full R.E.M. show has been released on CD

title: Stick 2 the Script
label: Showoff
description: Like an East Coast version of DJ Khaled, Massachusetts DJ/producer Statik Selektah has a nice thing going, consistently releasing surprisingly enjoyable, guest-crammed headknock-rap.

title: (k)no(w)here
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Wilderness return from a two-year hiatus with a few incremental shifts, including slower tempos, starker arrangements, and more emphasis on the band's superb rhythm section.

title: Hurricane
label: Wall of Sound
description: Fresh off of a winning appearance at the Massive Attack-curated Meltdown festival, the iconic singer who brought her distinctive presence to bear on disco and new wave returns with her first new album in almost 20 years.

title: I Am... Sasha Fierce
label: Columbia
description: Beyoncé follows other, uh, great ideas like Garth Brooks's proto-emo character Chris Gaines and T.I. vs. T.I.P with a split-personality 2xCD record.

title: Rubbed Out
label: Treader
description: Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor offes a low-key solo album á la Thom Yorke's The Eraser-- in this case, a refreshingly simple collection of tender ballads and quirky set pieces.

title: Stereo Image
label: Frog Man Jake
description: Johnny Dark, the one-time member of Junior Boys, whose skittering and spacious beats helped to define that group's seminal Last Exit, launches a new project with vocalist San Serac.

title: Footnotes 92-94
label: Cherry Red
description: Caught between shoegaze, Britpop, and, eventully, American indie, Adorable never got the recognition they deserved, something that this Cherry Red compilation aims to rectify.

title: Dømkirke
label: Southern Lord
description: Dømkirke-- a vinyl-only, 2xLP set recorded in March 2007 in a 12th century Norwegian cathedral-- showcases the metal band's impresice malleability and versatility. Members of Earth and Mayhem guest.

title: First Frost
label: Matinee
description: Dependable as ever, the Lucksmiths continue to put out quietly ambitious records that could be enjoyed by almost anybody who loves music-- not just indie pop partisans.

title: Dedication 3
label: self-released
description: After his tremendous 2008, Lil Wayne deserves a victory lap; unfortunately for us it's full of Auto-Tuned warbling and mediocre Young Money Entertainment signees.

title: Scratch Came, Scratch Saw, Scratch Conquered
label: Megawave
description: The second album from Lee "Scratch" Perry in just a few months, Scratch Came, Scratch Saw, Scratch Conquered finds the reggae legend contributing typically loopy off-the-dome vocals to productions by John Saxon. Guests include George Clinton and Keith Richards.

title: Cream Cuts
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Tussle's third album finds the San Francisco dub/dance combo finally becoming more comfortable in their own skin, but still too restrained and cerebral to achieve maximum release. Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor guests.

title: Arrowhead
label: Editions Mego
description: The latest of many 2008 releases by Hospital Productions mastermind Dominick Fernow tilts away from his (loosely speaking) "song"-based work and back to the realm of harsh and undeniably powerful noise.

title: Budokan!
label: Epic
description: Any band that's ever tried to weld a Beatlesque melody to a power chord owes a debt to Cheap Trick's classic live album, which now is blown up into a 3xCD/DVD, 30th-anniversary box set.

title: The BBC Sessions
label: Matador
description: Selecting from radio performances recorded between 1996 and 2001, including a set for the legendary John Peel, The BBC Sessions offers an appealing alternate portrait of Belle and Sebastian in their more ramshackle early days.

title: Play
label: EMI
description: This 1980 Australian live album captures the legendary (and now reunited) post-punk band Magazine in peak form, just a year before they disbanded.

title: Yancey Boys
label: Delicious Vinyl
description: J Dilla's younger brother trawls through the late producer's wealth of unused beats and uses them as the foundation for his debut album.

title: Sound Sculptures Volume 1
label: Sound Signature
description: A 2xCD set that follows a 3x12" 2007 release of the same name, this expanded version of Sound Sculptures Volume 1 shows the diversity of the house producer's vision, ranging from fully realized vocal songs to minimal tracks built from defiantly crude beats.

title: We Are Beautiful, We Are Doomed
label: Wichita
description: Just eight months after the release of their debut album, Los Campesinos! already return with the follow-up-- a messy, glorious, noisy document of internet café-era indie life that sounds best when sung by heart.

title: Welcome to Mali
label: Because
description: Amadou & Mariam reached international acclaim after 2005's Dimanche à Bamako; they follow that with a more global record featuring guests from France, the Ivory Coast, and Canada, as well as Englishman Damon Albarn.

title: Crack
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: Busy Houston MC's sixth Rap-A-Lot offering sounds drab and more than a little lonely; guests include Slim Thug and Paul Wall.

title: Hallam Foe OST
label: Domino
description: Director David Mackenzie's strange coming of age tale is soundtracked by Scottish bands including Franz Ferdinand and Orange Juice, with further contributions from Domino artists including Clinic, Juana Molina, and Junior Boys.

title: Exposion
label: Transmission
description: One of the last year's great unsigned indie rock bands, Austin's twitchy and unpredictable White Denim finally release their proper U.S. full-length debut.

title: NYC
label: Domino
description: On their fourth collaboration, Four Tet's Kieran Hebden and jazz drummer Steve Reid sound more in-tune with one another than ever before.

title: Parallax Error Beheads You
label: Domino
description: After six years, Max Tundra finally follows 2002's Mastered by Guy at the Exchange, a record that is passionately, obsessively, and madly loved by quite a few music-geek types for its strikingly unique sound, what seems to be a whole other realm of pop music that exists mostly inside one guy's head.

title: Starfucker
label: Badman
description: Despite their fierce live presence, this Portland, Ore. trio's debut strips them of their visual appeal, rhythmic heft, and onstage electricty.

title: Silence Is Wild
label: Secretly Canadian
description: An idiosyncratic, piano-playing singer-songwriter in the mold of Regina Spektor and Nellie McKay, Frida Hyvonen's second album wrings big ideas and bigger choruses from sparse instrumentation.

title: By-the-Numbers
label: Unfiltered
description: The Postmarks follow their lavish, loungey debut with a record of covers, featuring takes on numerical songs by Blondie, Astrud Gilberto, JAMC, and more.

title: Body Language Vol. 7
label: Get Physical
description: Following last year's fantastic Asa Breed, Michigan-based DJ/producer Matthew Dear issues this mix of minimal techno and deep house on Berlin's famed Get Physical label.

title: Trying Hartz
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Trying Hartz, a 2xCD, 28-track best-of collection, is a second point of entry for Danielson newcomers, a guide through Daniel Smith and family's dense, hit-or-miss pre-Ships affairs.

title: Nature's Got Away
label: K
description: This one-time Phil Elverum disciple still puts forth tattered arrangements and a battered delivery on his latest K Records release.

title: Nights Out
label: Because
description: After a solid stretch of singles and remixes, this UK squelch-pop group aims to make a successful transition from producer to album-oriented act.

title: Neji/Tori
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: These Japanese avant-rockers have a decade-long history but no releases until now available outside of their home country; this collection of two EPs includes tracks like "Sonic Youth" and "This Heat", named for bands they admire.

title: Fordlândia
label: 4AD
description: The second installment of a planned trilogy, Icelandic composer Jóhann Jóhannsson's new record is full of gorgeously sweeping strings aided by gently babbling electronics.

title: A Hundred Things Keep Me Up at Night
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: Love Is All's second album is a logical sequel to 2005's debut Nine Times That Same Song, wherein the group follows the cycle of making out and falling out by talking us through the subsequent sadness of single life.

title: JJ Got Live RaTX
label: Drag City
description: With JJ Got Live RaTX (actually a falsely advertised studio album), ex-Royal Trux woman Jennifer Herrema exorcises every last vestige of her former band's avant-rock influence and finally gets to enjoy the hair-metal 1988 she never got to experience the first time around.

title: Dark Developments
artist: Vic Chesnutt, Elf Power, and the Amorphous Strums
label: Orange Twin
description: An almost inevitable meeting of Athens, Ga., scene vets yields an album of songs-- written and sung by Chesnutt, though the stamp of other musicans is evident-- that cut the prevailing sense of doom with a mood of communal cheer.

title: Alpinisms
label: Ghostly
description: Secret Machines' Benjamin Curtis and On!Air!Library!'s Alejandra and Claudia Deheza have enjoyed an on-and-off collaboration for years, and it pays off on this album, full of synthetic pleasures and cavernous production.

title: Live at the Triple Door
label: Infernal
description: Recorded over two nights at a benefit for a Seattle music and arts center, this set of mostly stripped-down Twilight Singers is now available as a digital exclusive.

title: Berlin: Live At St. Ann's Warehouse
label: Matador
description: Lou Reed and Berlin producer Bob Ezrin always had their eyes on a stage adaptation of this narrative; in 2006, that finally became a reality, with appearances by Sharon Jones and Antony Hegarty. This is the soundtrack to a Julian Schnabel film about those performances.

title: Who Killed Harry Houdini?
label: Mute
description: Making more nuanced use of orchestration and sticking with a comfortingly sweet and naïve tone, this ginormous Swedish group attempts to avoid a sophomore slump.

title: Twilight of the Thunder God
label: Metal Blade
description: Their album covers overflow with swords, shields, and he-men, and they've been known to don drinking horns and offer a toast to live crowds, but the most "viking" aspect of these Swedish metalers could be their strong, simple, and often romantic melodies.

title: With Blasphemy So Heartfelt
label: Polymer
description: After singing on the latest Black Keys record, 19-year-old singer/songwriter Jessica Lea Mayfield crafts a bootgazing record about romantic passivity that's bathed in dreamy country production.

title: There’s Me and There’s You
label: !K7
description: The second album from Matthew Herbert's Big Band outfit; as the handle implies, there's an aesthetic shift from electronic music to avant-jazz at play here, but these are also songs with stronger, more overtly global and political themes than he's ever explored before.

title: The Renaissance
label: Interscope
description: After a ridiculously long and convoluted voyage, the former Tribe MC finally releases his first solo album in nine years-- and it's a tight refining of both classic boom-bap and fusion experimentalism.

title: Presents: Skull Gang Takeover
label: Datpiff.com
description: The new mixtape from Dipset member Juelz Santana and his Skull Gang crew assumes that there's a sector of hip-hop listeners that thought Cam'ron's Killa Season was too cerebral and uplifting.

title: Xs on Your Eyes
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: Brooklyn band with chamber-pop inclinations combines horns, classical guitar, and pedal steel on songs with deceptively dark overtones.

title: Ode to J. Smith
label: Red Telephone Box
description: After the comeback-via-throwback of The Boy With No Name, Travis go back even further into their history with its quick follow-up-- namely, to the first song on their first record: "All I Wanna Do Is Rock".

title: Reefer
label: Alpha Pup
description: Islands' Nick Thorburn teams with L.A. hip-hop producer Daddy Kev for his third record of the year, following his primary band's sophomore effort and the debut of folk duo Human Highway. Busdriver guests, while Flying Lotus and Dntel provide remixes.

title: Movement / Power, Corruption and Lies / Low-Life / Brotherhood / Technique [Collector's Editions]
label: Rhino
description: Movement / Power, Corruption and Lies / Low-Life / Brotherhood / Technique [Collector's Editions]

title: Sebastien Grainger and the Mountains
label: Saddle Creek
description: In contrast to his former Death From Above 1979 partner's MSTRKRFT project, Sebastien Grainger's debut solo effort ventures down a more conventional rock path with tracks built loosely on the singer-songwriter template.

title: Disgorge Mexico
label: Relapse
description: Keeping one foot in grindcore while the other plays a game of Twister with electronics, noise, and feints at jazz, Ottawa's Fuck the Facts have created their heaviest album yet.

title: Resurgam
label: Anticon
description: The producer and rapper returns with an album that reflects recent developments in the anticon. label, focusing on hip-hop while remaining flexible and incorporating elements of more abstract electronic music and indie rock. Guests include Why? and the One AM Radio.

title: Little Joy
label: Rough Trade
description: Strokes drummer Fabrizio Moretti hooks up with Brazilian Rodrigo Amarante and crashes at Devandra Banhart's, and he winds up casually making the best record involving any of his bandmates in years.

title: Surfing
label: Vapor
description: Devendra Banhart and Priestbird's Greg Rogove team up for a record that falls firmly in the "screwing around" category of side projects, with the duo unleashing styled silliness as well as some genuine treats.

title: Glorytellers
label: Southern
description: Geoff Farina of Karate and Secret Stars assembles a band to perform songs he wrote on a beat-up flamenco guitar while ensconced in a secluded cabin in the mountains of northern Italy.

title: Never Never Love
label: Counter
description: After starting as a sort-of convincing Marc Bolan clone, Pop Levi crafts a record that mostly concerns itself with a bizarrely and proudly quote-unquote inauthentic experiment with 80s textures.

title: The Inbetween
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: British-born singer and songwriter Essie Jain's second album is heavy with an odd, pervasive uneasiness-- it's a quiet, desperate, trembling testament to general disillusionment.

title: Tapes
label: !K7
description: Filled with classic and current disco, house, and electro tracks, this official mix from the Rapture will either satisfy or frustrate, depending on whether you're looking for a tastemaker with a great record collection or a straight-up momentum-building DJ.

title: Heart On
label: Downtown
description: Queens of the Stone Age's Josh Homme returns with a new record from his other band, revealing a slightly maturing sense of pop songcraft despite their endearingly juvenile lyrics.

title: Invisible City
label: Seventh Rule
description: On their second full-length, New York's Wetnurse reinvent Led Zeppelin as a punk band, incorporating a bevy of sonic elements that reflect the eclecticism of their hometown.

title: High Time
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Chicago band's latest experiments bring the group in the vicinity of dub reggae, eerie funk, and tricky post-rock, all executed with playfulness and a sense of mystery.

title: Chunk of Change EP
label: Frenchkiss
description: Starting out as a Valentine's Day gift for Passion Pit leader Michael Angelakos' girlfriend, this set of lap-pop serenades deftly walks the line between beat-driven, Hot Chip floor geeking and twee atmospherics.

title: Convivial
label: Huume
description: After the relative disappointment of Paper Tigers, Vladislav Delay's fourth Luomo album rewires the project, forging new emotional and sonic territory, marshalling enormous amounts of studio wizardry and compositional effort to map out a new (effortless-sounding) textural and sensual approach to house and pop music.

title: A Hundred Million Suns
label: Geffen
description: Though wide-screen preciousness is Snow Patrol's forte, the band's newest album, A Hundred Million Suns, is noticeably lighter on surging, megawatt stadium-filling fare, instead placing more emphasis on nuance.

title: qhnnnl
label: Southern
description: Featuring contributions from fellow Chicagoan Andrew Bird, as well as members of Tortoise, the Coctails, and Rachel's, Dianogah return after a six-year hiatus to prove they still have more than a few tricks up their sleeve.
